Braun Supervision Writing - review & editing a a School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, USA School of Mechanical Engineering Purdue University West Lafayette IN USA School of Mechanical Engineering, Purdue University, West Lafayette, IN, USA b Energy Technologies Area, Building Technology & Urban Systems Division, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, CA, USA Energy Technologies Area, Building Technology & Urban Systems Division Lawrence National Berkeley Laboratory CA USA Building Technology and Urban Systems Division, Lawrence National Berkeley Laboratory CA, USA ⁎ Corresponding author at: Energy Technologies Area, Building Technology & Urban Systems Division, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, CA, USA Energy Technologies Area, Building Technology & Urban Systems Division Lawrence National Berkeley Laboratory CA USA “Free cooling” with cool outside air can meet or reduce a building’s cooling loads in an energy efficient manner when conditions are favorable. For rooftop air conditioning units (RTUs), this is achieved with air-side economizers that are integrated with the packaged RTU. However, current RTU economizers are independently controlled at the unit level and may not fully leverage the free resource for economic benefit especially when multiple units serve a common zone of a building, such as in retail stores. That is, the independent control of multiple RTUs could lead to some units operating with mechanical cooling even when the outdoor air temperature or enthalpy is low enough to meet the load with economizer cooling. This paper presents a model-predictive control (MPC) approach to optimally supervise multiple RTUs in order to fully utilize the free cooling resource. The algorithm is applied to the evaluation of the energy savings potential for a case study building served by four identical RTUs under various climate zones over a cooling season. Because economizers are able to reduce the usage of vapor-compression mechanical cooling by utilizing the “free” cooling resource of the outdoor air when outdoor air conditions permit, a considerable amount of HVAC energy consumption can be saved through economizers. Therefore, many studies can be found in the literature (1) to assess energy savings potential of economizers for various climate zones for many countries, (2) to establish appropriate high limit economizer shut off criteria, and (3) to develop advanced economizer control algorithms for fully exploiting the free cooling resource. Zmeureanu [1] evaluated energy savings of an economizer for a cooling system operating in a Canadian climate (Montréal) using hourly weather data over ten years. The estimated reduction of the cooling-coil load and energy savings were about 50%. Olsen et al. [2] investigated several different HVAC systems under UK climate conditions including chilled ceilings, displacement ventilation, natural ventilation, night cooling, and a traditional VAV system, and concluded the systems that maximize free cooling from outside air have the best energy performance. Budaiwi [3] studied the potential for energy savings when the economizer cycle is employed under three climatic conditions in Saudi Arabia: hot-humid summer and mild winter; moderate summer and winter; and hot-dry summer and cold winter. Buluta and Aktacira [4] evaluated free cooling potential in Turkey. Wacker [5] studied energy savings potential and indoor comfort implications of economizer controls for packaged rooftop HVAC equipment under weather conditions in Asheville, North Carolina, U.S. Tayler and Cheng [6] performed comprehensive studies to establish appropriate economizer mode switch controls and the corresponding setpoints for various U.S. climate zones. Seem and House [7] developed model-based and optimization-based economizer control strategies and compared them with traditional economizer controls, i.e. differential dry-bulb temperature and differential enthalpy controls, for multiple climates. Wang et al. [8] developed an advanced rooftop unit control (ARC) that integrates an enhanced economizer control and provided site evaluation results. For rooftop air conditioning units (RTUs), air-side economizers are (optionally) integrated with the packaged RTU. Despite a long history of economizers, current equipment-level RTU economizer controls may not fully leverage the free resource especially when multiple units serve a common open space of a building, e.g. retail stores. In other words, the controls may turn on compressors although the outdoor air temperature or enthalpy is low enough to meet building’s cooling loads. The goal of this paper is to demonstrate such cases, to develop a model predictive control (MPC) for those open space buildings to overcome this issue, and to evaluate the energy savings potential of the MPC using simulations. For several decades, vast research activities of applying MPC to buildings have been carried out. In [9], authors discussed opportunities of implementing MPC for commercial buildings. Reviews [10,11] addressed challenges, aspects and future trends of MPC for commercial buildings. The need for future research on the automated creation and model updates for MPC was emphasized. Similarly, authors in [12] raised ten questions of applying MPC to buildings and provide challenges, future trends, and potential of MPC for the general building market. The identified challenges include high modeling effort, shortage of modeling and optimal control experts active in the building automation domain, and lack of commercial tools for expert-free building modeling. Technical aspects of MPC for building applications, from selecting a building response model, simulation timestep, prediction horizon, forecast resolution, to optimization algorithm, can be found in for example [10]. We refer to [13] for a more recent and comprehensive review on MPC for buildings. Despite the large number of studies, the vast majority of MPCs have been focused on large sized commercial buildings (which are served by individual air handling units), and therefore only a few studies can be found in the literature for open-space building applications (which are served by multiple RTUs). Nutaro et. al. [14] developed a MPC for a gymnasium having four identical units. This controller is to limit electric peak power demand and about 15% of demand reduction with respect to a conventional thermostat control was achieved. Kim et. al. [15] developed a MPC for minimizing energy consumption and peak demand for open space buildings. The control design was focused to minimize sensor and configuration requirements in order to enable a cost effective control implementation for small and medium sized commercial buildings. About 10% building HVAC energy savings and about 30% peak demand reduction were reported for a building. Biyik et. al. [16] developed a RTU coordinator aiming at minimizing peak power and reported that the peak power reduction with the MPC was about 20–40% for existing buildings. Putta et. al. [17] utilized dynamic programming to solve an optimization problem for minimizing energy consumption and penalizing compressor cycling. In a simulation study, about 10% energy savings were achived for a building served by 4 RTUs. Zhange et. al. [18] developed a MPC for RTUs for load shedding during demand response events while minimizing comfort impacts. Despite these MPC developments for coordinating multiple RTUs, none of them considered economizers in MPCs and therefore their performance is limited. Note that, in the U.S., RTUs are used in about 50% (2.1 million) of all commercial buildings, serving over 60% (3.6 billion m 2 ) of the commercial building floor space and consuming about 2.4 × 10 8 GJ annually [8]. Consequently, even a small improvement in economizer operation could lead to a significant reduction of national energy use. Section 2 provides a review of economizer logic for commercial RTUs to develop a realistic economizer control sequence that will be used in the simulation study. A MPC which aims at improving energy performance is introduced in Section 3. Section 4 describes a simulation testbed for a case study building where the MPC and a conventional economizer control are compared. With the simulation platform, cases where the conventional control lead to poor energy performance are shown in Section 5. Behaviors of the MPC under the same simulation conditions are also included. Finally, energy savings analysis for the case study building for U.S. climate zones are provided in Section 6. 2 Investigation of rooftop unit economizer logic This section provides a summary of the sequence of operations for economizers in commercial rooftop units. Seven different economizers were reviewed (Lennox LGH/LCH RTUs, TRANE ReliaTelTM, Carrier 48HJD/HJE/HJF RTUs, Johnson controls J**ZH/ZJ/ZR RTUs, Honeywell economizer, PREMIERLINKTM Retrofit Rooftop). This review was used to provide a realistic simulation testbed for evaluating the MPC. 2.1 Thermostat controls It is important to describe a typical thermostat control for the packaged units, since RTU economizer controls are associated with thermostat signals. In general, a thermostat is dedicated to an RTU and turns one or more compressor stages on and off to maintain a local zone air temperature near a setpoint. The first stage, or the first call for cooling (Y1), is typically energized when the thermostat temperature rises above the setpoint by a deadband, say 1 ° F (0.55 ° C ). The Y1 signal is maintained until the thermostat temperature goes below the setpoint. If the temperature continues to increase and rises above the setpoint by a 2nd stage deadband, then the 2nd stage, or the 2nd call for cooling (Y2), is energized. The Y2 signal is maintained until the temperature goes below the setpoint. Many thermostats have internal anti-cycling clocks to protect compressors from short cycling. That is, once the call for cooling switches to ON, the status is maintained for say 5 min regardless of the thermostat temperature. For some thermostat controls, the reverse action is true. That is, once the call for cooling switches to OFF, the status holds for a time period although the thermostat temperature could rise above the deadband during the period, again for the safety issue. The supply fan is typically on continuously during the occupied period and can cycle with the compressor during unoccupied times. Most RTUs in the field do not have variable-speed compressors or fans controlled by variable frequency drives. The economizer control sequence relies on the thermostat control with the interface variable of the call for cooling. 2.2 Review of rooftop unit economizer controls There are a number of ways of enabling and disabling the economizer mode, or the free cooling mode, depending on available sensors and economizer controllers. Typical types are fixed dry-bulb temperature, differential dry-bulb temperature, fixed enthalpy, differential enthalpy and combinations of those, e.g. fixed enthalpy with fixed dry-bulb temperature. Once an outdoor air sensor measurement, e.g. dry-bulb temperature, exceeds a pre-specified high-limit shutoff control setting, the economizer mode is disabled. The economizer shutoff control setting could be configured as a fixed value or with a curve (if an enthalpy sensor is available). For the former, ASHRAE standard 90.1 [19] provides guidelines for the settings depending on U.S. climate zones and sensor types. For the latter case, the economizer mode is enabled once the point of the outdoor air condition in the psychrometric chart is located on the left hand side of a predefined curve (denoted as A,B,C,D) in the chart. For some units, the control logic for the economizer mode has a dead-band, e.g. 5°C for the dry-bulb temperature case, such that the mode is maintained until the outdoor air condition changes sufficiently. Once the economizer mode is disabled, the signals of first call (Y1) and second call (Y2) for cooling bypass the economizer logic module such that the RTU operates based on thermostats as usual: Y1 and Y2 correspond to the 1st and 2nd compressor stage respectively. In this case, the outdoor air (OA) damper is at a minimum position which can be specified by users. Once the economizer mode is enabled and the first call for cooling is received from a thermostat, outside and return air dampers begin to modulate in order to maintain the supply air temperature at around 55 ° F while disabling mechanical cooling. The controlled variable could be the mixed air temperature upstream of the evaporator rather than the supply air temperature. Depending on the sensor position, unit performance would be different for the case when the mechanical cooling is integrated with the economizer damper control. However, most economizers regulate the supply air temperature. ON–OFF control with a deadband or a PI controller are used for the supply air temperature regulation. An example of the on/off control algorithm is: When the supply air temperature goes below 50 ° F (10 ° C ), the OA damper is modulated to minimum position, and when it goes above 56 ° F (13 ° C ) the damper is modulated to fully open. When the supply air temperature is in the 50 ° F and 56 ° F range, the damper position is held constant. When the economizer mode is activated, the economizer action for the on–off control approach can result in cycling behavior like for single-stage mechanical cooling. When free cooling cannot satisfy the first call for cooling, it leads to a 2nd call for cooling. When Y2 is energized, an economizer engages the first stage compressor, while the outside and return air dampers continue to modulate to maintain a suitable supply air temperature. More precisely, the economizer damper control loop is independent of the Y2-signal. Optionally, if the integrated economizer action is not enough to eliminate a 2nd call for a period of time, then economizers can turn on a 2nd stage compressor. The time delay is adjustable by users but a default setting is typically long, for example, a 2-h delay. 2.3 Development of economizer control logic for simulation tests To evaluate a model predictive control algorithm for economizer equipped RTUs within a simulation testbed, economizer control logic was implemented on the review of commercial RTU economizers. The logic is for a two-stage unit where (1) the economizer mode is triggered by a fixed OA dry bulb, (2) an analog economizer damper is controlled with a PI controller and (3) the 2nd stage mechanical cooling is not available during the economizer mode, e.g. due to a long delay setting. It is shown in the algorithm. Lines from 10 to 26 describe the following: ”Once the economizer mode is enabled (see line 10) and the first call for cooling is received from a thermostat (see line 13), outside and return air dampers begin to modulate in order to maintain the supply air temperature (see lines from 14 to 25) while disabling mechanical cooling (see line 26)”. Lines from 14 to 25 are the control action for a PI controller with an anti-windup (or integral reset) strategy which tends to modulate the OA damper position v to maintain the supply air temperature at a setpoint T SA , SP with proportional and integral gains as shown in lines from 14 to 16. When the calculated control decision v ′ is saturated, the integral error and damper position reset in order to avoid the integral windup. The aforementioned control sequence of ”When Y2 is energized, an economizer engages the first stage compressor” is shown in lines from 28 and 30. It is an extension of a previously developed MPC, namely the Unit Coordinator [20]. For detailed descriptions and performance evaluations of the original unit coordinator for multiple field sites, refer to [15]. Some modifications of the MPC were made in this paper to consider economizers. 3.1 General formulation Remember that when an RTU is integrated with an economizer, the 1 st stage could mean either the economizer only mode or 1 st stage mechanical cooling depending on the status of economizer mode. Likewise, the 2nd stage means either the integrated mode between the economizer and 1 st stage mechanical cooling or the 2nd stage mechanical cooling (see the previous section). Consider a building equipped with N u number of packaged air conditioning units. Let N s ( i ) be the total number of stages for the i th unit. Let P i , s be the rated power for the s th stage of the i th unit. Note that P i , 1 could mean the fan power associated with the economizer only mode or the unit power (compressor and fan) associated with the 1 st stage mechanical cooling, depending on the activation status and availability of the economizer for the i th unit. That information can be found in manufacturer’s data. The control problem at a current time step k is to find optimal stage trajectories to minimize energy consumption, demand upper bound and comfort violations. That is: (1) min ( ∑ j = 0 N p - 1 ( ∑ i = 1 N u ( ∑ s = 1 N s ( i ) P i , s u i , s ( k + j ) ) ) + ω d δ + ω l Γ l + ω u Γ u s . t . T l - Γ l ⩽ y i ( k + j + 1 ) ⩽ T u + Γ u ( ∀ i ∈ { 1 , ⋯ , N u } ) (2) ∑ i = 1 N u ( ∑ s = 1 N s ( i ) P i , s u i , s ( k + j ) ) ⩽ δ ( ∀ j ∈ { 0 , ⋯ , N p - 1 } ) (3) u i , N s ( i ) ⩽ ⋯ ⩽ u i , 2 ⩽ u i , 1 ( ∀ i ∈ { 1 , ⋯ , N u } ) (4) u i , s ( j ) ∈ { 0 , 1 } ( ∀ i ∈ { 1 , ⋯ , N u } , ∀ s ∈ { 1 , ⋯ , N s ( i ) } ) (5) δ ⩾ 0 , Γ l ⩾ 0 , Γ u ⩾ 0 where y i ( j ) is the thermostat temperature for the i th unit at the j th time step. u i , s ( j ) ∈ { 0 , 1 } represents on/off mode for the s th stage of the i th unit at the j th time step. u i , s are strictly binary (either 0 or 1) rather than integers and are variables to be decided. For example, consider two units where the first is a two-stage unit while the second is a single-stage unit. In this case, N s ( 1 ) = 2 and N s ( 2 ) = 1 and, at a given time j , u 1 , 1 ( j ) , u 1 , 2 ( j ) and u 2 , 1 ( j ) are the decision variables. The optimization problem is to minimize a weighted sum of the multiple objectives of energy consumption, peak power and comfort violations with some weights 1 1 In this paper, values of 10, 100 and 100 were used for ω d , ω l and ω u . The first term in the objective function indicates the sum of powers for all stages for all units over the prediction horizon of N p . δ in the second term indicates an upper bound of the sequence of the instantaneous HVAC powers over N p , as shown in the second constraint. Γ l , Γ u in the last two terms represent comfort (temperature) violations from user-specified upper and lower bounds for thermostat temperatures as shown in the first constraint. The third inequality constraint is to ensure that the 2nd stage should be activated after the 1 st stage is on, for example. The optimization variables are u i , s ( j ) ∀ i , s , j and δ , Γ l , Γ u . The optimization problem is mixed integer linear programming (MILP) and hence can be solved numerically efficiently and reliably. It should be noted that the MPC is designed to coordinate units for a relatively short prediction horizon, e.g. 30 min. 3.2 Further description Because of the aforementioned anti-cycling clocks (typically a 5-min interval) to protect compressors from a very short cycling, the proposed MPC has been implemented for every 5 min in this study. At each sampling time, it is assumed that the information of the status of the economizer mode for each unit is available, e.g. through BACNET. Then, the powers of P i , s are adjusted accordingly. Once they are specified, the MILP problem is solved. For example, consider two two-stage units where only one unit has an economizer. When the outdoor air temperature is cold enough such that the economizer mode for the first unit is enabled, the MILP with ( P 1 , 1 , P 1 , 2 ) = ( 0.2 , 1.2 ) (kW) and ( P 2 , 1 , P 2 , 2 ) = ( 1.2 , 2.2 ) (kW) is solved where 0.2, 1.2 and 2.2 represent the (rated) fan power for the economizer only mode, the unit power for the 1st stage mechanical cooling, and that for the 2nd stage mechanical cooling, respectively. On the other hand, when the outdoor air temperature is warm enough, the optimization problem with ( P 1 , 1 , P 1 , 2 ) = ( 1.2 , 2.2 ) (kW) and ( P 2 , 1 , P 2 , 2 ) = ( 1.2 , 2.2 ) is solved. First, note that the MPC considers the overall building’s behaviors, i.e. energy consumption, electric peak demand and temperature violations. Therefore, it is a centralized control. Second, when the outside temperature is cold enough, stage powers for the economizer-equipped unit are lowered so that the optimal point could move towards the utilization of that unit. This means the optimization tends to distribute overall building load towards the energy efficient units. Last, note that the MPC only adjusts the thermostat signals of the call for cooling and therefore no modification or interruption for internal economizer controllers is required. This feature is practically important for deploying the MPC in real applications. For implementing the control in practice, methodologies to reject unmeasured disturbances during both modeling and control phases should be addressed. Our proposed approaches for the disturbance rejection are explained in the following two sections. 3.3 Control oriented modeling The MPC requires a model that maps a sequence of unit stages into that of thermostat temperatures. In this paper, we adopted the approach introduced in [21] which was developed for modeling open space areas served by multiple RTUs for small and medium sized commercial buildings. It assumes a simple model structure in an attempt to capture major dynamics of the complex system. An example RC network for a two-zone (i.e., two thermostat) system is depicted in Fig. 1 . Each zone is composed of two thermal capacitances and two thermal resistances, and is served by its own unit having capacity of Q ̇ i . Zone air nodes are connected by a resistance denoted as R zz in the figure. Corresponding differential equations for the i th zone are; (6) C z , i T ̇ z , i = 1 R zw , i ( T w , i - T z , i ) + ∑ k = 1 , k ≠ i n 1 R zz , ki ( T z , k - T z , i ) + 1 R zo , i ( T o - T z , i ) + Q ̇ g , i + Q ̇ i u i C w , i T ̇ w , i = 1 R zw , i ( T z , i - T w , i ) . T z , i is the local zone air (thermostat) temperature and T w , i is a local wall temperature representing averaged behaviors of the building enclosure. T o , Q ̇ i are the outdoor air temperature, and mechanical heat rate for the i th zone. u i ∈ Z represents a RTU stage and is expressed as u i = ∑ s = 1 N s ( i ) u i , s 2 2 For example, for a two-stage unit, when the first and second stages are both ON (that is, u i , 1 = 1 , u i , 2 = 1 ), u 1 = 2 . On the other hand, when only the first stage is ON (that is, u i , 1 = 1 , u i , 2 = 0 ), u 1 = 1 . . C z , i and C w , i represent thermal capacitances of the zone and wall. R zw , i and R za , i are thermal resistances between the zone air and wall, and between the zone air and ambient air, respectively. R zz , ki = R zz , ik is the effective thermal resistances between the k th and i th zone. The total number of interzonal resistances is the number of 2-combinations from the total number of units N u , and hence is N u ! / ( ( N u - 2 ) ! 2 ! ). Q ̇ g , i represents unmeasured input disturbances, e.g. occupancy gains, lighting loads and transmitted solar radiation. The parameters to be estimated are denoted as θ which consists of C w , i , C z , i , R zw , i , R zo , i , Q ̇ i and R zz , ki , ∀ i , k ∈ { 1 , ⋯ , N u } . The dimension of θ is 5 N u + N u ! / ( ( N u - 2 ) ! 2 ! ) . After a matrix manipulation of (6), a linear time invariant (LTI) state space model structure was derived, θ was identified with an input and output dataset, and the estimated LTI model was used for the MPC to predict y i in response to a control action of u i , s . The lumped output disturbance modeling approach introduced in [21,22] that was developed to alleviate impacts of unknown disturbances, i.e. Q ̇ g , i , on the estimated dynamic model has been applied for the identification process. It should be mentioned that 1) the modeling approach (from a design of experiments to an identification algorithm) was fully automated for a large scale MPC deployment in the past, and 2) what we are interested in this paper is performance of the integrated control approach, i.e. the modeling + MPC, rather than that of an individual model. Therefore the performance assessment of the integrated control approach was focused in this paper. However, we refer to [21] for comprehensive theoretical and experimental analysis of the modeling approach itself, and [15] for its practical MPC application for multiple sites. 3.4 Dealing with uncertainties during control phase The practical implementation of a MPC suffers from uncertainties of a model mismatch and inaccurate or corrupted measurements. The issue is important for the proposed small and medium sized commercial building applications, because they do not have a sufficient number of sensors for various heat gain sources, such as occupancy gains, lighting loads and transmitted solar radiation. To mitigate this concern, a strategy, namely the offset-free MPC, was utilized in this paper and is described as follows. The dynamic model (6) can be expressed as (7) x k + 1 = Ax k + Bu k y k = Cx k where x represents the local zone air and wall temperatures, u is the RTU stage and y is the local zone air temperatures. In the offset-free MPC strategy, the model (7) is augmented with a disturbance model. In this work, the so-called output disturbance model was utilized which leads to the following Kalman filter form. (8) x k + 1 p k + 1 ︸ x k + 1 = A 0 0 I ︸ A x k p k ︸ x k + B 0 ︸ B u k + K e k , y k = C I ︸ C x k p k , where e is the innovation term that is the difference between the measurement and model prediction, p is an internal dynamic state to model unmeasured disturbances, and K indicates the Kalman gain. By comparing (8) with (7), it can be seen that the model prediction y of the augmented model is corrected with p that is the integration of the prediction errors (see the first equation of (8)): this allows compensating the model mismatch and unmeasured disturbances with the real time feedback. K was obtained by solving the Discrete-time Algebraic Riccati Equation, and the augmented model described by ( A , B , C , K ) in (8) was utilized to estimate dynamic states of x and p and predict y i in the MPC problem (1). The overall procedure is standard for the off-set free MPC strategy which can be found, for example, in a graduate textbook [23]. Although the method is not yet popular in the field of building controls, it has been well developed and widely used in other control fields, the chemical process engineering in particular. We refer to [24,25] for other industrial applications and theoretical investigations, and [26] for a building MPC application. 4 Description of simulation platform Recall that we are interested in buildings that utilize multiple RTUs serving open spaces, which are very common in the U.S. Unfortunately, popular building energy simulation tools, e.g., EnergyPlus [27] and TRNSYS [28], that are based on the fully-mixed indoor air assumption are not appropriate for our purposes in these open-space buildings. In the absence of considering spatial temperature variations: (1) all RTUs would be simultaneously activated or be deactivated since their thermostats would always see the same temperatures for a fully-mixed model; (2) simultaneous on/off actuation of all RTUs would lead to very unrealistic responses of thermostat temperatures to feedback control signals compared to reality; (3) the assumption that all RTUs operate with the same on/off cycling would lead to significant errors in prediction of part-load performance and peak electrical demand. These issues are less important for estimation of monthly or annual energy consumption assuming that time-average zone air temperatures track set-points, but are critical for testing the proposed MPC [29]. Therefore, we utilized an advanced building model that is able to capture spatial temperature and humidity variations. The model couples a reduced-order computational fluid dynamics (CFD) model for the interior air with a reduced-order building envelope model and HVAC models in order to provide realistic dynamic response to feedback control by the thermostats. Since describing the advanced modeling approach is not the purpose of this paper, we refer to [29] for detailed descriptions of the modeling approach. However, in this paper, we present a summary of the methodology and model validation results against field measurements. It starts with developing two linear time invariant (LTI) models for indoor air and building envelope systems. Computational fluid dynamic (CFD) simulations were performed using a commercial CFD software, and simulation results were used to tune parameters for a state space description for the indoor air system to obtain a reduced-order CFD model. For the building envelope system, based on building geometry information and wall/window properties, a LTI envelope model was developed using the formula described in [30] which has been validated through comparisons with existing Building Energy Simulation tools such as TRNSYS [28]) for several buildings. The two LTI models for building envelope and indoor air were integrated to eliminate the coupling variables of (1) inner wall temperatures and (2) convective heat fluxes between the inner wall and zone air (the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map). Then, the aggregated model is integrated with detailed HVAC equipment models to complete the reduced-order CFD-coupled building model. For a thorough description including mathematical details, we refer to [20,29]. The case study building is a gymnasium ( 100 ft × 100 ft , 30.5 m × 30.5 ) served by four identical single-speed fan, two-stage RTUs. Fig. 2 shows the RTU layout and interior of the case study building. The four RTUs serve different quadrants of this rectangular open space. Four thermostats are located on wall surfaces in quadrants. Based on geometrical and physical information of the building, e.g. types of wall/window and shapes and locations of supply diffusers/return vents, a reduced-order CFD coupled building model was developed. For experimental validation, measured input data was fed to the integrated reduced-order CFD model. Corresponding model outputs were recorded for comparison with measured outputs. As measured inputs, the supply air temperature ( T sup ) for each RTU and the outdoor air temperature were selected. Due to technical issues (e.g. low sampling rate and time delay of thermostats), the return air temperatures ( T r , i ) to the RTUs were selected as outputs instead of thermostat temperatures. The return air temperature sensors are located at the upstream inlets of the RTUs. Supply air temperature sensors were located downstream of the units. In order to eliminate uncertain disturbances due to occupants and solar loads, the experiments were performed during night time hours. A sample input data set for model validation is shown in Fig. 3 . Corresponding output comparisons associated with the input data are shown in Fig. 4 (See Fig. 2 for the RTU numbering associated with the different plots). For each plot (i.e., each RTU), the blue line represents the output response for return air temperature of the coupled model, whereas the red line is the measured output. The model properly captures the dynamics due to RTU cycling with the standard deviation of output errors with respect to measurements are less than 0.5 ° C , which is very satisfactory. Fig. 5 shows the input data for a different day and the output comparisons for the input data are shown in Fig. 6 . Again, the responses of the model match well with the measured outputs with less than 0.5 ° C standard deviations. Overall, the reduced-order CFD coupled building model captures the important dynamics of the indoor air. 5 Demonstration cases for energy savings The load distribution problem is to decide how to distribute loads over multiple units: It is the reverse of the resource allocation problem [31] which seeks to find a way of allocating a fixed amount of resources to different entities in an economic manner. Since a conventional thermostat control (Conv) is totally decentralized and does not consider overall building performance, it could distribute building loads poorly such that inefficient units or modes take a large portion of cooling loads. On the other hand, as mentioned, the MPC can be viewed as an algorithm to solve the optimal load distribution problem, since it tends to utilize economizer enabled units, which are the most efficient units or modes, as much as possible, when free cooling is available. Therefore, the energy savings potential of the MPC depends on how the Conv behaves. In this paper, we show two different cases where the Conv distributes building loads poorly to conversely demonstrate that there is significant energy savings potential of the MPC. For the simulations, it was assumed that a unit must stay ON for a 5-min interval(anti-cycling clock) once it turns on. In addition, we assumed that there is no anti-cycling clock for the thermostat to switch to the OFF mode. 5.1 Case 1: all units have economizers In this simulation study, we considered the case where all four units for the gymnasium are equipped with economizers. It is assumed that the gymnasium is located at Los Angeles, U.S. (3C climate zone). The economizer mode is determined by a dry-bulb outdoor air temperature and the economizer shut off temperature was set to 75 ° F ( 23.89 ° C ) based on ASHRAE 90.1. Fig. 7 shows the outdoor air temperature for a sample period. Note that it is below the high limit temperature setting, i.e. 75 ° F ( 23.89 ° C ) for all times, which means economizers were always enabled for the simulation period. Fig. 8 shows responses of thermostat temperatures, RTU staging and total HVAC power associated with the conventional control (Conv). In the first subfigure, the black solid line represents thermostat setpoint schedule and the others indicate profiles of the four thermostat temperatures. The blue solid and red dashed lines in the 2nd to 5th subfigures indicate the thermostat call for cooling and compressor stage, respectively. The first stage (Y1) and second stage (Y2) correspond to the economizer only mode and integrated mode (economizer and mechanical cooling), respectively, in the sample period. Note that mechanical cooling occurred for the RTU1 and RTU3, while the RTU2 and RTU4 were off for most of times. To explain why this happens, look at the temperature profiles for the RTU2 and RTU4 in the 1st subfigure. At the beginning of the simulation, say until 5:00 AM, the temperatures are lower than that of the RTU1 and RTU3. At 7:00 AM the RTU1 starts to cycle. Because it is an open-space building, the cooling influences all other thermostats which reduces the chances of distributing the building load evenly. As the building loads increase, say during afternoon, a majority of building loads went to the RTU1 and RTU3 causing unnecessary mechanical cooling for those units. Note that the mechanical cooling could be removed by utilizing free cooling resources for the RTU2 and RTU4. The simulation results demonstrate a poor load distribution performance for the Conv. Fig. 9 shows responses of the MPC. In the 2nd to 5th subfigures, it can be seen that mechanical cooling has not been used for all times of this simulation period and thermostat temperatures were maintained within a similar range. Note that free cooling resources of the RTU2 and RTU4 were utilized through the MPC, even though their temperatures were below the setpoint. This desired behavior is because the MPC solves an optimal building load distribution problem and thereby it allocates the building load heavily to the most efficient stage, i.e. the economizer only mode. The HVAC power in the last subfigure is only due to operation of the RTU fans for this simulation period. In comparison to Fig. 8, these results show substantial savings potential for both energy and electric peak demand costs associated with coordinating economizers. The simulation results demonstrated that the non-uniform spatial distribution of thermostat temperatures is one of the main reasons causing a poor load distribution for the conventional control. To demonstrate this can happen in practice, experimental test results for the same building are shown in Fig. 10 . The upper and lower figures show building behaviors for different days during mild weather of September in Tennessee (US). For the upper figure, it can be confirmed that the thermostat temperatures for the RTU2 and RTU3 were relatively lower (about 0.5 ° C ) than the others. Although this gap seems not very significant, it results in significantly biased unit operations: cooling for the RTU2 and RTU3 were not used for most of times while building loads were met by RTU3 and RTU4 with 2nd stage cooling. Similar behavior can be observed in the second subfigure. From available measurements for other sites that include retail stores and restraints, the same pattern has been confirmed. Since non-uniform thermostat temperature distributions are unavoidable in practice and it is not likely that the decentralized control evenly distributes building load, it is expected that the poor performance of distributing loads for conventional control is usual. 5.2 Case 2: half of units have economizers In this case, it is assumed that two units, the RTU1 and RTU2, are equipped with economizers. That is, only mechanical cooling modes are available for the other two units of the RTU3 and RTU4. All other simulation parameters were the same as those for Case 1. Figs. 11 and 12 show system responses under the Conv and MPC, respectively. Like Case 1, the Conv is not able to fully exploit free cooling resources: free cooling resources for the RTU2 were not used (see the 3rd subfigure of Fig. 11). This is simply because the Conv does not know which modes are efficient and leads to an operation of units in an inefficient way. On the other hand, from 2nd and 3rd subfigures of Fig. 12, the MPC has enabled the efficient economizer mode for the RTU2 for many times which shows that the MPC is able to leverage available free cooling resources. By comparing the last subfigures, around one third of the HVAC energy was saved through the MPC for this time period. 6 Assessment of model predictive control energy savings potential in multiple climate zones As discussed, the MPC optimally distributes building loads toward efficient economizer operations when free cooling is available. Therefore, the energy savings potential of the MPC significantly depends on the availability of free cooling resources. Simulation studies have been performed for multiple climate zones, indicated by circles in Fig. 13 , to investigate the variation of the savings potential. The shut-off limits for enabling and disabling economizers used in this simulation study are summarized in Table 1 , which are based on ASHRAE 90.1. Recall that a fixed-dry bulb economizer is used in this simulation study. Due to a high computation time, only 4-month simulations were performed from April to July using TMY3 data for the locations. Fig. 14 summarizes MPC energy savings for the different locations. The left and right figures correspond to Case 1 (four economizers) and Case 2 (two economizers), respectively. For climate zones 1A, 2A, 3A and 2B, energy savings are small at around 5%. This makes sense because free cooling resources are not available most of the time for these zones. On the other hand, substantial energy savings of up to 30% occur for climate zones 3B, 3C, 4C, 5B, 5C zones. Note that economizer installation is required for these climate zones by the ASHRAE Standard 90.1. The savings results for Case 1 show that the unnecessary energy use of the Conv due to its poor load distribution caused by a non-uniform spatial temperature distribution is substantial. Intuitively, the large energy savings of around 15–30% for climate zones where economizers are required make senses since (1) the conventional control does not consider which operational modes are efficient, (2) efficiencies for the economizer mode and mechanical cooling modes are substantially different, and (3) free cooling resources are largely available for these zones. 7 Conclusions This paper presented a MPC algorithm, which can be used for real applications, and evaluated energy savings potential of optimally supervising multiple RTU economizer operations. Comprehensive simulation studies for an open space served by four two-stage rooftop units were performed to evaluate energy savings potential for a model predictive control algorithm over a 4-month cooling season in different climate zones. Very significant energy savings of 15% to 30% were achieved through the controller for most of the climate zones where economizer installations are mandatory. It was found that conventional thermostat control poorly distributes building loads towards inefficient mechanical cooling modes even when all units have economizers. This is attributed to a nonuniform thermostat temperature distribution and a strong coupling between units. In contrast, the model predictive controller favors economizer operation when appropriate and generally operates the most efficient modes while maintaining local temperatures close to the setpoints. coredata.dc:description: “Free cooling” with cool outside air can meet or reduce a building’s cooling loads in an energy efficient manner when conditions are favorable. For rooftop air conditioning units (RTUs), this is achieved with air-side economizers that are integrated with the packaged RTU. However, current RTU economizers are independently controlled at the unit level and may not fully leverage the free resource for economic benefit especially when multiple units serve a common zone of a building, such as in retail stores. That is, the independent control of multiple RTUs could lead to some units operating with mechanical cooling even when the outdoor air temperature or enthalpy is low enough to meet the load with economizer cooling. This paper presents a model-predictive control (MPC) approach to optimally supervise multiple RTUs in order to fully utilize the free cooling resource. The algorithm is applied to the evaluation of the energy savings potential for a case study building served by four identical RTUs under various climate zones over a cooling season.
coredata.dc:title: Model predictive control for supervising multiple rooftop unit economizers to fully leverage free cooling energy resource
